moves.1. Nf3: The Reti Opening. My first thoughts were 'Well, it looks like I'll be learning how to play against this opening'. I have only played this opening once, a long time ago.
moves.1... d5 2. c4: The usual follow-up for the Reti.
moves.2... dxc4: I capture. Is the Reti a kind of temporary gambit?
moves.3. Nc3: Why is e4 rarely played at this point? It develops a central pawn and lets the LSB attack the pawn on c4.
moves.3... Nc6: I try to catch up in development, as well as contest e5 so my e-pawn can move there.
moves.4. e4: White grabs some of the centre.
moves.4... e5 5. Bxc4: We are now equal in material again, with white having a positional edge.
moves.6. O-O: Castling and removing his king from possible danger later on.
moves.6... Nf6: White is still ahead in development, but the pawns on d2 and b2 are going to hinder the development of his DSB slightly.
moves.7. a3: I don't really know why this was played. I guess to prevent Bb4, but I wouldn't threaten his knight with my bishop while it's defended.
moves.7... O-O: I castle. Our levels of piece development are now equal.
moves.8. d3: White clears up space for his DSB.
moves.8... Bg4: I pin White's knight, completing my minor piece development. The White Queen is also somewhat restricted in that I get to open up White's kingside if the queen quits the defence of the knight.
moves.10... h6 11. Bxf6: He takes the knight, allowing me to develop my queen.
moves.11... Qxf6: Adding pressure to the knight on f3.
moves.12... Qd8: Moving back to my original square.
moves.13. Qb3: ?! This may be threatening the pawn on b7, but it allows me to mess up White's kingside with Bxf3.
moves.13... Bxf3 14. gxf3: Now I can begin to pressure White's kingside.
moves.14... Qg5+: Check, while developing my queen again.
moves.15. Kh2: Hmm... Would Kh1 have been better?
moves.15... Nd4: Forking the queen and pawn on f3 while getting my knight closer to the action.
moves.16... Qd2: ! A decoy/temporary sacrifice, which wins a pawn at worst.
moves.17. Qxd2: As you can see, I am behind in material by a queen. I'll regain it pretty quickly, though.
moves.17... Nxf3+: Taking a pawn with check. White is forced to give up his queen advantage.
moves.18. Kg3 Nxd2: Taking the queen while threatening the rook.
moves.19. Rfd1: Best, because 19. Nxc7 Nxf1+ 20. Rxf1 Rac8.
moves.21. Nc7: ?? This allows me to trap the knight with Rac8.
moves.21... Rac8 22. Rd7: Protecting the knight. I initially overlooked this, but then realised that White is trading while behind.
moves.23. Rxd8+: White didn't really have much choice: he loses the inight anyway.
moves.23... Rxd8: The knight is no longer threatened, but it is still trapped.
moves.25. b5: ?? White overlooked the threat on his rook.
moves.25... Bxa1 26. f4: Offering another trade, which I will gladly accept, especially as it comes with check.
moves.26... exf4+ 27. Kxf4 Rc8: Faced once again with the loss of his knight and with a large material disadvantage, White resigns here. Good game atom842.
